   [**9-19**] CT Head (Preliminary read):
   Hypoattenuating region in the left frontal lobe, and bifrontal subdural
   fluid
   collections are unchanged from one day prior on non-contrast study.
   [**9-19**] RUQ U/S: Nodular heterogenous liver is non-specific, but may be
   secondary to underlying liver disease. No evidence of cholecysitis.
   Small volume ascites
   [**9-19**] Transthoracic Echo: The left atrium is normal in size. Left
   ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic
   function are normal (LVEF >55%). Right ventricular chamber size and
   free wall motion are normal. There is focal thickening of the right
   coronary cusp of the aortic valve which measures 0.5 x 0.5 cm; cannot
   exclude valvular vegetation. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No
   aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are
   structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. No mass or
   vegetation is seen on the mitral valve. No mitral regurgitation is
   seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There
   is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion.
   IMPRESSION: Focal thickening of the right coronary cusp of the aortic
   valve without aortic regurgitation. Cannot exclude aortic valve
   vegetation. If clinically indicated, a TEE would better assess for
   endocarditis. Preserved regional and global biventricular systolic
   function.
   Culture data: (new results) Serum Toxoplasma IgM and IgG both negative.
   [**9-17**] Stool culture negative for campylobacter, shigella, salmonella.
   [**9-19**] Blood cultures NGTD x2, Sputum gram stain >25 PMNs, 4+ GNR, 2+
   budding yeast. [**Doctor First Name **] (+) 1:160. Aspergillous antigen negative. Toxo PCR
   CSF negative.
   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria brain
   abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Given last ABG from [**9-18**], can go down
   on Fi02 (currently at 40%).
   - Will continue current ventilator settings, as she is doing well on 8
   of PS and 5 of PEEP. Ideally would like to wait to see if mental status
   improves before considering extubation.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her. Will follow up iron levels as a high level may pre-dispose to
   listeria infection per ID's note. At this time, left frontal mass
   suspected to be listeria abscess, (per chart notes) neurosurgery feels
   that given positive culture data, should treat this medically without
   surgical intervention.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 3. Will
   need to check gent level 30 minutes prior to 4th dose (tomorrow).
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will follow up final CT abdomen results
no evidence of abscess noted
   on preliminary read however.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - Formal TTE request placed to evaluate for endocarditis (will continue
   to monitor PR interval) as source of bacteremia.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylasis, ativan in event of seizure; will
   hold phenytoin given elevated corrected level (today corrected level is
   26.3)
   - Currently checking daily head CT (yesterday, today), then every other
   day for 2 days, then will re-assess.
   - EEG to check for seizure activity given lack of responsiveness.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input.
   - Follow up pending serologies as noted above.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Will consider trial of holding SQ Heparin to see if PTT improves
   (overall coags are within baseline since admission)
   - Continuing to follow head CT
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient with elevated LFTs, will continue to monitor
   trend. Will follow up CT abdomen final read, and if LFTs further
   elevated, will check RUQ ultrasound to better evaluate gall bladder and
   CBD.
   -          RUQ as noted above.
   -          Cont to try to obtain outside records
   #) Hypernatremia: Was only getting 30 mL q6H, increased to 150 mL. Will
   recheck in PM.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease.
- She presented with seizure and was found to have Listeria brain abscess.
- She is currently in the ICU for respiratory failure and is intubated for airway protection.
- She has Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess.
- She has pancytopenia, which may be due to Imuran toxicity or other causes.
- Her elevated INR may be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
- She has elevated liver function tests, which need to be monitored.
- She has hypernatremia and is receiving aggressive hydration.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. The ABG results indicate the need to decrease FiO2 and continue with current ventilator settings. There is a risk of further deterioration in respiratory function if the mental status does not improve.

2. Listeria Infection: The patient has Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess. She is being treated with ampicillin and gentamicin, but there is a concern for endocarditis as a potential source of bacteremia. The presence of a focal thickening of the right coronary cusp of the aortic valve without aortic regurgitation on the transthoracic echo raises the possibility of aortic valve vegetation.

3. Pancytopenia: The patient has pancytopenia, which may be due to Imuran toxicity or other causes. Monitoring of trend, transfusion if HCT <21-22 or symptoms, and repeat retic count is advised.

4. Elevated INR: The elevated INR may be secondary to nutritional deficiencies or other causes. Holding SQ Heparin to see if PTT improves and continuing to monitor for the possibility of DIC are recommended.

5. Elevated LFTs: The patient has elevated liver function tests, which need to be monitored. Further evaluation of the gallbladder and CBD may be necessary if LFTs further elevate.

6. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, and aggressive hydration is being provided. Rechecking in PM and adjusting fluid intake accordingly is advised.

Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), bacterial meningitis, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, and hemolytic anemia. The patient's medical history includes hypertension and atrial fibrillation. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 102.5°F (39.2°C), heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 121/55 mmHg to 149/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, with a tidal volume of 370 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 77,000/uL, elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) at 195 mg/dL, anemia with a hemoglobin level of 7.3 g/dL, and thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 74,000/uL. Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have a listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated for respiratory failure and on mechanical ventilation. The patient is also experiencing pancytopenia, elevated INR, and hypernatremia. She has been treated with antibiotics for listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess. The patient's condition remains unchanged, and she is unresponsive to commands. Neurosurgery has decided to treat the frontal mass medically without surgical intervention. The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, and elevated liver function tests. Imaging studies reveal a hypoattenuating region in the left frontal lobe and bifrontal subdural fluid collections.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. There is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and further deterioration in respiratory status.
2. Listeria infection: The patient has a confirmed listeria brain abscess and bacteremia. There is a risk of complications related to the infection, such as abscess progression, meningitis, or sepsis.
3. Pancytopenia: The patient has low levels of white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets. This can increase the risk of infections, bleeding, and other

The patient's condition is critical, and she is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. She is also in a coma and has ongoing fevers. The patient has anemia, hyperglycemia, and hepatitis, and is being treated with various antibiotics, including ampicillin and gentamicin. The patient's prognosis is uncertain, and further evaluations and consultations are planned.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is primarily due to her neurologic status. There is a consideration for an early tracheostomy if appropriate and if the patient is expected to recover in weeks to months.
2. Listeria Infection: The patient has a disseminated Listeria monocytogenes infection with identified sites including brain abscess, meningitis, bacteremia, and possible subdural empyema. This infection needs to be closely monitored and managed with appropriate antibiotics.
3. Coma: The patient is unresponsive and in a coma. Prognostic information for the family and further evaluation by neurology are needed.
4. Hepatitis: The patient has signs of hepatitis, and outside records need to be obtained to help sort out the diagnostic data supporting autoimmune hepatitis.

   connecting the non-coronary cusp of the aortic valve, the anterior
   mitral valve apparatus, and the interatrial septum that could be

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   c-collar in place limit the ability to extubate her. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Will consider trial of extubation versus proceeding straight to
   tracheostomy.
   - Will continue to think forward regarding her respiratory status, as
   it may take considerable time for neurologic recovery to occur. Options
   include possible trial of extubation if c-collar can be removed, or
   proceeding to a tracheostomy. Will consider breathing trial tomorrow.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her, and an iron overloaded state would alsopre-dispose to listeria
   infection per ID's note. At this time, left frontal mass suspected to
   be listeria abscess, (per chart notes) neurosurgery feels that given
   positive culture data, should treat this medically without surgical
   intervention.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 4,
   gentimicin dose checked this morning. Will determine proper once daily
   dosing of gentimicin.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input
will discuss further what the
   predicted recovery may be based on limited patient and case report data
   to help guide family and further management.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE requested to evaluate for abscess and vegetation given that TTE
   could not rule out abscess. Appreciate cardiology assistance. Will
   monitor EKGs for evidence of PR prolongation.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylasis, ativan in event of seizure; will
   hold phenytoin given elevated corrected level (today corrected level is
   26.3)
   - Currently checking daily head CT (yesterday, today), then every other
   day for 2 days, then will re-assess per neurosurgery. Currently will
   continue to treat medically, but need to consider tapping subdural
   collections at some point if no improvement (concern for subdural
   empyema).
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input, will call with questions.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every day or two.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient with elevated LFTs, will continue to monitor
   trend. Today all down or stable except for alkaline phos. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team
   this morning, listeria can have similar presentation to viral
   hepatitis.
   -          Called this morning to obtain records: patient was
   hospitalized at [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 841**], CA initially for first episode of
   elevated liver function tests, then followed up with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 979**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 980**] at
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 981**], OR, where she had her liver biopsy and MRCP.
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, etc. She will need more free water repletion, so
   went up from 30 mL q6H, increased to 150 mL. Will recheck in PM to
   ensure it is improving.
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely a listeria brain abscess. The patient is currently intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status. There are several potential medical complications that could arise based on the information provided:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's elevated respiratory rate may be secondary to her CNS process. She may require a trial of extubation versus proceeding straight to tracheostomy.

2. Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess: The patient has positive cultures for listeria in her blood and CSF. She is being treated with ampicillin and gentamicin. If there is no improvement, consideration may be given to tapping subdural collections due to concern for subdural empyema.

3. Pancytopenia: The patient has elevated MCV with pancytopenia consistent with Imuran toxicity. Other possibilities include B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. Further monitoring and management are required.

4. Elevated INR: The patient's elevated INR may be secondary to nutritional deficiencies. She has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at presentation. Monitoring of coagulation parameters will continue.

5. Elevated LFTs: The patient's elevated liver function tests

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 65-year-old male with a chief complaint of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). 
- The patient has been admitted to the ICU since 9/15/2124.
- The patient has had several medical events, including fever, hypotension, and positive guaiac test indicating gastrointestinal bleeding.
- The patient's allergies include no known drug allergies.
- The patient has been receiving various medications, including insulin, heparin, phenytoin, and others.
- The patient's vital signs show elevated temperature, low blood pressure, and increased respiratory rate.
- The patient's blood tests reveal leukopenia, anemia, elevated liver enzymes, and abnormal coagulation profile.
- The patient's imaging studies show evidence of SAH and bilateral low-density subdural fluid collections, but no new hemorrhage or significant changes.
- The transesophageal echocardiogram shows normal left atrium, no masses or thrombi, and trivial regurgitation in the mitral and tricuspid valves. However, there is a small amount of thickening and echolucency around the fibrous structures connecting the non-coronary cusp of the aortic valve, the anterior mitral valve apparatus, and the interatrial septum, which could be consistent with abscess in the appropriate clinical setting.
- The patient's cultures are pending or show no growth since admission.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   limits the ability to extubate her. Her elevated respiratory rate is
   likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Discussed at length risks and benefits of trial of extubation in this
   patient. Her RSBI is encouraging, but her mental status remains very
   poor. Concern would be for complications if she was failed extubation
   and was difficult to re-intubate.
   - Based on the fact that it is expected the patient would likely remain
   intubated for the foreseeable future, and based on discussions of team
   with family, will consult IP for trach and PEG. Appreciate IP
   assistsance.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her, and an iron overloaded state would alsopre-dispose to listeria
   infection per ID's note. Today there is concern for possible worsening
   mental status, as it took more stimuli for withdrawal and she may not
   have been opening her eyes as she was before. Her CT head yesterday was
   without change. Given question of change in mental status, will check
   head CT again today. If there are any changes in her imaging concerning
   for worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 4,
   gentimicin dose checked this morning. Will determine proper once daily
   dosing of gentimicin.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input
will discuss further what the
   predicted recovery may be based on limited patient and case report data
   to help guide family and further management.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE requested to evaluate for abscess and vegetation given that TTE
   could not rule out abscess. Appreciate cardiology assistance. Will
   monitor EKGs for evidence of PR prolongation.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylasis, ativan in event of seizure; will
   hold phenytoin given elevated corrected level (today corrected level is
   26.3)
   - Currently checking daily head CT (yesterday, today), then every other
   day for 2 days, then will re-assess per neurosurgery. Currently will
   continue to treat medically, but need to consider tapping subdural
   collections at some point if no improvement (concern for subdural
   empyema).
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input, will call with questions.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every day or two.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient with elevated LFTs, will continue to monitor
   trend. Today all down or stable except for alkaline phos. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team
   this morning, listeria can have similar presentation to viral
   hepatitis.
   -          Called this morning to obtain records: patient was
   hospitalized at [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 841**], CA initially for first episode of
   elevated liver function tests, then followed up with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 979**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 980**] at
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in [**Location (un) 981**], OR, where she had her liver biopsy and MRCP.
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, etc. She will need more free water repletion, so
   went up from 30 mL q6H, increased to 150 mL. Will recheck in PM to
   ensure it is improving.
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.

The patient is currently intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status. She has respiratory failure and is likely to remain intubated for the foreseeable future. The team has decided to consult interventional procedures for tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) given the expected prolonged need for mechanical ventilation and nutritional support.

2. Listeria Bacteremia and Meningitis/Encephalitis/Abscess: The patient has listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess. The team is treating this with ampicillin and gentamicin. They will continue to follow culture data and monitor the patient's mental status and imaging.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   limits the ability to extubate her. Her elevated respiratory rate is
   likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Discussed at length risks and benefits of trial of extubation in this
   patient. Her RSBI is encouraging, but her mental status remains very
   poor. Concern would be for complications if she was failed extubation
   and was difficult to re-intubate.
   - Based on the fact that it is expected the patient would likely remain
   intubated for the foreseeable future, and based on discussions of team
   with family, will consult IP for trach and PEG. Appreciate IP
   assistsance.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her, and an iron overloaded state would alsopre-dispose to listeria
   infection per ID's note. Today there is concern for possible worsening
   mental status, as it took more stimuli for withdrawal and she may not
   have been opening her eyes as she was before. Her CT head yesterday was
   without change. Given question of change in mental status, will check
   head CT again today. If there are any changes in her imaging concerning
   for worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 5. Level
   yesterday was <2, which is goal for once daily dosing.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE as noted
no definite vegetation or abscess seen, but
   abnormalities as noted above.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylaxis, tomorrow initiating keppra 1000 mg
   [**Hospital1 **] and stopping phenytoin. Combination of two overlapping
   anti-epileptics could be part of reason for decreased mental status.
   Corrected phenytoin level today is 25.
   - Head CT from last two days without change, checking today to ensure
   no further change given question of change in mental status. If
   unchanged, will check on Saturday, and then again on Monday.
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Will work on optimizing reversible factors such as hypernatremia,
   adding lactulose in event that there is a degree of hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input, will call with questions.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team this morning, listeria
   can have similar presentation to viral hepatitis.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible
   losses. She will need more free water repletion, so increased FW
   flushes to 200 mL Q4H, as wish to avoid D5W in event this may worsen
   cerebral edema (no significant edema at present however).
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   #) Finger lesion: Per family, lesion has been present for several
   months. Differential includes foreign object, infection, insect bite.
   No fluctuance or fluid expressed.
   - Will request dermatology consult for further evaluation, appreciate
   assistance.
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigement over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: Unclear if this represents true
   infection, but suspect at present this is likely not true pneumonia as
   she does not have a significant amount of sputum, no leukocytosis, and
   overall fever curve has improved. Chest x-ray also remains unimpressive
   for infection. Will have low threshold to initiate treatment, and will
   have respiratory therapy complete a mini-BAL today to collect further
   culture data.
   #) Hypotension: Patient with transient hypotension this morning. This,
   coupled with her hypernatremia, borderline tachycardia, dry mucous
   membranes, all support volume depleted state. Will continue LR boluses
   to keep up urine output >40-50 cc/hour, SBP >90, and HR<100.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with seizure and was found to have listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely listeria brain abscess. The patient is currently intubated for respiratory failure and altered mental status. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated due to respiratory failure. There is a risk of complications if extubation fails or if the patient develops further respiratory issues.

2. Listeria infection: The patient has listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess. There is a risk of worsening mental status and potential neurological complications.

3. Pancytopenia: The patient has elevated MCV with pancytopenia, which may be consistent with Imuran toxicity. Monitoring and further evaluation are necessary to manage this condition.

4. Elevated INR: The patient has an elevated INR, which could be due to nutritional deficiencies. Close monitoring and appropriate management are required.

5. Elevated liver function tests (LFTs): The patient has stable elevated LFTs, likely secondary to liver disease. Regular monitoring is necessary.

6. Hypernatremia: The patient has persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible losses. Free water repletion and careful management are needed.

7. Finger lesion: The patient

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   c-collar in place limit the ability to extubate her. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Will discuss with trauma surgery or spine surgery removal of her
   c-collar. Concern is that if this remains in place, she cannot be
   easily re-intubated should she fail a trial of extubation. CT c-spine
   was negative for any pathology.
   - Will continue to think forward regarding her respiratory status, as
   it may take considerable time for neurologic recovery to occur. Options
   include possible trial of extubation if c-collar can be removed, or
   proceeding to a tracheostomy. Will consider breathing trial tomorrow.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her, and an iron overloaded state would alsopre-dispose to listeria
   infection per ID's note. At this time, left frontal mass suspected to
   be listeria abscess, (per chart notes) neurosurgery feels that given
   positive culture data, should treat this medically without surgical
   intervention.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 4,
   gentimicin dose checked this morning. Will determine proper once daily
   dosing of gentimicin.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input
will discuss further what the
   predicted recovery may be based on limited patient and case report data
   to help guide family and further management.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE requested to evaluate for abscess and vegetation given that TTE
   could not rule out abscess. Appreciate cardiology assistance. Will
   monitor EKGs for evidence of PR prolongation.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylasis, ativan in event of seizure; will
   hold phenytoin given elevated corrected level (today corrected level is
   26.3)
   - Currently checking daily head CT (yesterday, today), then every other
   day for 2 days, then will re-assess per neurosurgery. Currently will
   continue to treat medically, but need to consider tapping subdural
   collections at some point if no improvement (concern for subdural
   empyema).
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input, will call with questions.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every day or two.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Patient with elevated LFTs, will continue to monitor
   trend. Today all down or stable except for alkaline phos. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team
   this morning, listeria can have similar presentation to viral
   hepatitis.
   -          Called this morning to obtain records: patient was

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), meningitis, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, and hemolytic anemia. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation. He has been febrile since admission and has had multiple positive cultures indicating bacterial infections. The patient's condition remains unstable, and the prognosis is difficult to assess due to prolonged seizures and fevers.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged intubation, there is an increased risk of developing VAP. Regular assessment of respiratory status and cultures should be performed to detect any signs of infection.
2. Sepsis: The patient has severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, indicating a systemic inflammatory response. Close monitoring of vital signs, blood cultures, and organ function parameters is necessary to manage sepsis effectively.
3. Meningitis: Bacterial meningitis has been diagnosed, and the patient may be at risk for complications such as brain abscesses or ventriculitis. Repeated neurologic assessments and appropriate antibiotic therapy are essential.
4. Hemolytic anemia: The patient has hemolytic anemia, which can lead to complications like acute kidney injury or cardiac issues. Monitoring of hemoglobin levels, blood counts, and electrolytes is crucial.
5. Organ dysfunction: The patient's organs, including the

   and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear

   mitral valve. However, there is a small amount thickening and
   echolucency around the fibrous structures connecting the non-coronary
   cusp of the aortic valve, the anterior mitral valve apparatus, and the
   interatrial septum that can be consistent with abcess in the
   appropriate clinical setting. Normal tricuspid leaflets with trivial
   tricuspid regurgitation. No masses or vegetations are seen on the
   tricuspid valve. No vegetation/mass is seen on the pulmonic valve.
   There is no pericardial effusion.
   Impression: No vegetation on the cardiac valves. Small amount of
   fibrous tissue thickening/echolucency in the fibrous structure
   connecting the non-coronary cusp of the aortic valve, the anterior
   mitral valve apparatus, and the interatrial septum that could be
   consistent with abcess in the appropriate clinical setting. No other
   intracardiac source of thrombus is identified. Normal biventricular

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have lLsteria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   limits the ability to extubate her. Her elevated respiratory rate is
   likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Discussed at length risks and benefits of trial of extubation in this
   patient. Her RSBI is encouraging, but her mental status remains very
   poor. Concern would be for complications if she failed extubation and
   was difficult to re-intubate.
   - Based on the fact that it is expected the patient would likely remain
   intubated for the foreseeable future, and based on discussions of team
   with family, trach and PEG. Appreciate IP assistsance.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her. There is concern for possible worsening mental status, as now does
   not appear to withdraw to noxious stimuli. Her CT head has been
   stable.  If there are any changes in her imaging concerning for
   worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 6. Level
   Gent yesterday was <2, which is goal for once daily dosing.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE as noted
no definite vegetation or abscess seen, but
   abnormalities as noted above.
   - Initiated keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] and stopping phenytoin. Combination of
   two overlapping anti-epileptics could be part of reason for decreased
   mental status.
   - Head CT from last two days without change, checking today to ensure
   no further change given question of change in mental status. If
   unchanged, will check on Saturday, and then again on Monday.
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Will work on optimizing reversible factors such as hypernatremia,
   adding lactulose in event that there is a degree of hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - This AM FDP 10-40, hapto <20, could be hemolyzing for unclear reasons
   (no literature for Keppra as cause of hemolysis); sending Coombs test,
   will d/w Heme today
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Transfusing 2 units for Hct 17, check post-transfusion Hct
   - Repeat hemolysis labs
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team this morning, listeria
   can have similar presentation to viral hepatitis.  Lipase elevated
   today
           -      recheck lipase
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible
   losses. She will need more free water repletion, so increased FW
   flushes to 150 mL Q3H, as wish to avoid D5W in event this may worsen
   cerebral edema (no significant edema at present however).
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   #) Finger lesion: Derm evaluated, foreign body with granuloma.
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: Unclear if this represents true
   infection, but suspect at present this is likely not true pneumonia as
   she does not have a significant/new amount of sputum, no leukocytosis,
   and overall fever curve has improved. Chest x-ray also remains
   unimpressive for infection. Will have low threshold to initiate
   treatment, respiratory therapy completed a mini-BAL yesterday that
   showed no microorganisms or PMNs.
   - Consider formal BAL today with trach
   # Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   #) Hypotension: Patient with transient hypotension overnight. This,
   coupled with her hypernatremia, borderline tachycardia, dry mucous
   membranes, all support volume depleted state. Monitoring closely for
   worsening sepsis. Will continue LR boluses to keep up urine output
   >40-50 cc/hour, SBP >90, and HR<100.
   ICU Care

   Tube feeds, NPO after midnight for trach/PEG this AM

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient is currently intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status. She has pancytopenia, elevated INR, and elevated liver function tests. The patient also has hypernatremia and is at risk for volume depletion. There are several other medical complications and conditions that need to be addressed, including potential fungal infection, respiratory failure, and nutritional deficiencies.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated and may require long-term mechanical ventilation. There is a concern for complications if she fails extubation and is difficult to re-intubate.
2. Listeria infection: The patient has Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely brain abscess. Treatment with ampicillin and gentamicin has been initiated, and it is important to monitor the response to antibiotics and culture data.
3. Pancytopenia: The patient has elevated MCV with pancytopenia, which could be due to Imuran toxicity, B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, or malignancy. Further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
4. Elevated INR: The patient's elevated INR could be secondary to nutritional deficiencies. It is

The patient is a 65-year-old male with a chief complaint of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). The patient has been admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and management. 

The patient's medical history includes meningitis, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, and hemolytic anemia. 

The patient is currently on multiple medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and other ICU medications. 

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.3 C (97.4 F), heart rate of 91 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 113/59 to 151/75 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. 

The patient's neurological examination reveals that he is not assessed for movement, tone, or response. 

Laboratory results show leukopenia with a white blood cell count of 3.7 K/uL, normal hemoglobin level of 5.9 g/dL, elevated blood glucose level of 164 mg/dL, and normal kidney function with creatinine level of 0.6 mg/dL. 

Imaging studies, including a head CT and chest CT, show no significant changes. 

The patient's fluid balance indicates a total intake of 3,794 mL and a total output of 1,374 mL, resulting in a positive balance of 2,420 mL.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status. Currently, her mental status and
   limits the ability to extubate her. Her elevated respiratory rate is
   likely secondary to her CNS process.
   - Discussed at length risks and benefits of trial of extubation in this
   patient. Her RSBI is encouraging, but her mental status remains very
   poor. Concern would be for complications if she was failed extubation
   and was difficult to re-intubate.
   - Based on the fact that it is expected the patient would likely remain
   intubated for the foreseeable future, and based on discussions of team
   with family, will consult IP for trach and PEG. Appreciate IP
   assistsance.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her, and an iron overloaded state would alsopre-dispose to listeria
   infection per ID's note. Today there is concern for possible worsening
   mental status, as it took more stimuli for withdrawal and she may not
   have been opening her eyes as she was before. Her CT head yesterday was
   without change. Given question of change in mental status, will check
   head CT again today. If there are any changes in her imaging concerning
   for worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 5. Level
   yesterday was <2, which is goal for once daily dosing.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE as noted
no definite vegetation or abscess seen, but
   abnormalities as noted above.
   - Phenytoin for seizure prophylaxis, tomorrow initiating keppra 1000 mg
   [**Hospital1 **] and stopping phenytoin. Combination of two overlapping
   anti-epileptics could be part of reason for decreased mental status.
   Corrected phenytoin level today is 25.
   - Head CT from last two days without change, checking today to ensure
   no further change given question of change in mental status. If
   unchanged, will check on Saturday, and then again on Monday.
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Will work on optimizing reversible factors such as hypernatremia,
   adding lactulose in event that there is a degree of hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - Follow up iron studies, DIC panel from this morning, repeat retic
   count.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - Appreciate hematology input, will call with questions.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Transfusing 2 units for Hct 17
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team this morning, listeria
   can have similar presentation to viral hepatitis.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible
   losses. She will need more free water repletion, so increased FW
   flushes to 150 mL Q3H, as wish to avoid D5W in event this may worsen
   cerebral edema (no significant edema at present however).
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   #) Finger lesion: Derm evaluated, foreign body with granuloma.
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigement over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: Unclear if this represents true
   infection, but suspect at present this is likely not true pneumonia as
   she does not have a significant/new amount of sputum, no leukocytosis,
   and overall fever curve has improved. Chest x-ray also remains
   unimpressive for infection. Will have low threshold to initiate
   treatment, and will have respiratory therapy complete a mini-BAL today
   to collect further culture data.
   #) Hypotension: Patient with transient hypotension this morning. This,
   coupled with her hypernatremia, borderline tachycardia, dry mucous
   membranes, all support volume depleted state. Will continue LR boluses
   to keep up urine output >40-50 cc/hour, SBP >90, and HR<100.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Tube feeds, NPO after midnight for trach/PEG
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin gtt/sliding scale.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated for respiratory failure and has pancytopenia, elevated INR, elevated liver function tests, hypernatremia, and hyperpigmentation. She is being treated with antibiotics for the listeria infection and is also receiving other medications such as phenytoin for seizure prophylaxis, famotidine, and heparin prophylaxis. The patient's condition remains critical, and she requires ongoing monitoring and treatment in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently intubated due to respiratory failure. There is a risk of complications if extubation fails or if the patient develops further respiratory distress.
2. Listeria Infection: The patient has listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a possible brain abscess. If the infection does not respond to treatment, there may be worsening of her mental status and potential complications.
3. Pancytopenia: The patient has pancytopenia, which can lead to an increased risk of bleeding and infection.
4. Elevated INR: The patient has an elevated INR, indicating a potential bleeding risk. Close monitoring and appropriate management are necessary to prevent bleeding complications.
5. Elevated Liver Function Tests: The patient

   patient. Her RSBI is encouraging, but her mental status remains very
   poor. Concern would be for complications if she failed extubation and

no definite vegetation or abscess seen, but

   mental status.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease, who presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. She is currently intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status and respiratory failure. The patient has pancytopenia, elevated INR, and elevated liver function tests (LFTs). She also has hypernatremia, hypotension, and a finger lesion with granuloma. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure if extubation is attempted and the patient does not respond well, worsening mental status due to the Listeria infection or other causes, complications from the pancytopenia such as infection or bleeding, bleeding due to the elevated INR, liver dysfunction, dehydration or electrolyte imbalances due to hypernatremia, and further deterioration of the finger lesion.

Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), bacterial meningitis, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, and hemolytic anemia. The patient has undergone various procedures including bronchoscopy, percutaneous tracheostomy, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) insertion.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.9°C (100.2°F), heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 80-90s, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow, set tidal volume of 400 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's physical examination reveals small cracks in the lips, no bleeding, moist mucous membranes, and edematous upper lip. The neck is supple with a flat jugular venous pressure (JVP). The lungs are rhonchorous bilaterally without wheezes. The cardiac examination shows a regular rhythm without murmurs, gallops, or rubs. The abdomen is slightly distended with bowel sounds present and a PEG in place. The extremities show 1+ pitting edema

   losses. She will need more free water repletion, but now NPG x 48 hrs,

The patient's neurological status is described as unresponsive with no eye opening and small withdrawal response to noxious stimuli.

   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, now POD 1 from trach. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.  Appreciate IP
   assistance.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her. There is concern for possible worsening mental status, as now does
   not appear to withdraw to noxious stimuli. Her CT head has been
   stable.  If there are any changes in her imaging concerning for
   worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 7. Goal
   gent <2 for once daily dosing.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE as noted
no definite vegetation or abscess seen, but
   abnormalities as noted above.
   - Initiated keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] and stopping phenytoin. Combination of
   two overlapping anti-epileptics could be part of reason for decreased
   mental status.
   - Head CT from last two days without change, checking today to ensure
   no further change given question of change in mental status. If
   unchanged, will check on Saturday, and then again on Monday.
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Will work on optimizing reversible factors such as hypernatremia,
   adding lactulose in event that there is a degree of hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   - ED recommending repeat LP on Monday.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - FDP 10-40, hapto <20, could be hemolyzing for unclear reasons (no
   literature for Keppra as cause of hemolysis); Heme evaluated smear, no
   evidence for hemolysis
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Hct stable post transfusion
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coag
s every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team this morning, listeria
   can have similar presentation to viral hepatitis.  Lipase elevated
   today
           -      recheck lipase
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from

s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible
   losses. She will need more free water repletion, but now NPG x 48 hrs,
   concern for giving D5W given CNS issues.

s, or

She is currently intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status and has undergone tracheostomy. The patient's respiratory failure is secondary to her CNS process.

The patient also has pancytopenia, likely caused by Imuran toxicity, as indicated by elevated MCV and pancytopenia. Other possible causes include B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. The patient's hemoglobin level is low, and she has received a blood transfusion.

The patient's elevated INR is suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies. There is no evidence of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), but the patient's coagulation status will continue to be monitored.

The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are overall stable, but there is evidence of liver disease, possibly due to Listeria infection. The patient's lipase is elevated, and further evaluation is needed.

The patient has persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible losses. She will need more free water repletion, but careful monitoring is required due to her CNS issues.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient has been diagnosed with several conditions. The patient's chief complaint is not specified in the note. The note mentions that the patient underwent a bronchoscopy, percutaneous tracheostomy, and PEG insertion on September 22nd. 

The patient's labs indicate hemolysis, but the peripheral smear is normal, and the bilirubin levels are down, making hemolysis unlikely. The patient's platelet count is low, and there are abnormalities in liver function tests (ALT, AST, Alk Phos, TBili) and kidney function (creatinine, BUN). The patient's electrolytes are also imbalanced (sodium, potassium). 

The patient's vital signs show stable blood pressure and heart rate, but the respiratory rate is on the higher end of the normal range. The patient is receiving supplemental oxygen through a tracheostomy tube and is on mechanical ventilation with a respiratory support system. 

The patient's physical examination findings are limited due to the fact that several assessments were not performed. 

The patient has multiple medical complications including subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), bacterial meningitis, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, and hemolytic anemia. 

In terms of ICU care, the patient is receiving nutrition, glycemic control, and has multiple lines including an arterial line and multi-lumen line. Prophylactic measures are in place for deep vein thrombosis

   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed

   stable.  If there are any changes in her imaging concerning for
   worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.

no definite vegetation or abscess seen, but

   unchanged, will check on Saturday, and then again on Monday.

   adding lactulose in event that there is a degree of hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.

Based on the provided information, the patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient is currently in the ICU and has been intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's elevated respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process. There is concern for worsening mental status, which could potentially lead to respiratory failure. Close monitoring and assistance with IP are required.

2. Listeria infection: The patient has Listeria bacteremia and meningitis, which can progress to encephalitis and abscess formation. It is crucial to continue with appropriate antibiotic therapy (ampicillin and gentamicin) and follow-up culture data. If there are any changes in imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, re-consult neurosurgery may be necessary.

3. Pancytopenia: The patient has elevated MCV with pancytopenia, consistent with Imuran toxicity. Other possibilities include B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. Monitoring the trend, transfusing if HCT <21-22 or symptoms, and considering TPMT status for increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment are important.

   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, now POD 2 from trach. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.  Appreciate IP
   assistance.
   -
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immunosuppressed state may have pre-disposed
   her. There is concern for possible worsening mental status, as now does
   not appear to withdraw to noxious stimuli. Her CT head has been
   stable.  If there are any changes in her imaging concerning for
   worsening edema or bleeding, will re-consult neurosurgery.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 7. Goal
   gent <2 for once daily dosing.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - TEE as noted
no definite vegetation or abscess seen, but
   abnormalities as noted above.
   - Initiated keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] and stopping phenytoin. Combination of
   two overlapping anti-epileptics could be part of reason for decreased
   mental status.
   - Head CT from last two days without change, checking today to ensure
   no further change given question of change in mental status. If
   unchanged, will check on Saturday, and then again on Monday.
   - EEG was not supportive of convulsive status.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Will work on optimizing reversible factors such as hypernatremia,
   adding lactulose in event that there is a degree of hepatic
   encephalopathy.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   - ID recommending repeat LP on Monday.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   - FDP 10-40, hapto <20, could be hemolyzing for unclear reasons (no
   literature for Keppra as cause of hemolysis); Heme evaluated smear, no
   evidence for hemolysis
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Hct stable post transfusion
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies.
   Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well as FFP's at
   presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be
   less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coags every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Per discussion with team this morning, listeria
   can have similar presentation to viral hepatitis.  Lipase elevated
   today
           -      recheck lipase
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible
   losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible
   losses. She will need more free water repletion, but now NPG x 48 hrs,
   concern for giving D5W given CNS issues.
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Start D5W gently to decrease Na as pt is now NPO/NPG until at least
   Monday
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: Unclear if this represents true
   infection, but suspect at present this is likely not true pneumonia as
   she does not have a significant/new amount of sputum, no leukocytosis,
   and overall fever curve has improved. Chest x-ray also remains
   unimpressive for infection. Will have low threshold to initiate
   treatment, respiratory therapy completed a mini-BAL yesterday that
   showed no microorganisms or PMNs.
   - Bronchial washings performed by IP: culture pending, no micro seen
   # Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   -  Sent beta glucan pre and post Amp dosing to ascertain whether
   elevated level is related to abx
   #) Hypotension: Patient with transient hypotension overnight. This,
   coupled with her hypernatremia, borderline tachycardia, dry mucous
   membranes, all support volume depleted state. Monitoring closely for
   worsening sepsis. Will continue LR boluses to keep up urine output
   >40-50 cc/hour, SBP >90, and HR<100.
   # Peg: Required two attempts, being monitored closely for evidence of
   leak in stomach/peritonitis.
   - Gastrograffin study Monday
   - IP following

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease who presented with a seizure. She was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient is currently in the ICU, intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status. She has been on ampicillin and gentamicin since September 17th.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's elevated respiratory rate may be secondary to her CNS process. She is intubated for airway protection, but there is a risk of respiratory failure if the intubation fails or if there are further complications.

2. Listeria infection: The patient has bacteremia and meningitis caused by Listeria, and there is a concern for worsening mental status. If imaging shows worsening edema or bleeding, neurosurgery consultation may be required.

3. Pancytopenia: The patient has elevated MCV with pancytopenia, which could be consistent with Imuran toxicity. Other possibilities include B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. Monitoring of trend and transfusion if HCT <21-22 or symptoms is recommended.

4. Elevated INR: The patient's INR is elevated, suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies. Vitamin K and FFPs have been given, and coagulation will be monitored every other day. DIC

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old female with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. She presented to the emergency department with altered mental status and was found to have septic shock secondary to a lower respiratory tract infection. She required intubation and mechanical ventilation and was admitted to the ICU.

Over the past 24 hours, the patient's condition has remained stable with no significant changes in her vital signs or neurological examination. However, she did experience a seizure episode this morning, which was treated with lorazepam. The head CT scan showed no new abnormalities.

The patient continues to receive gentamicin, ampicillin, furosemide, pantoprazole, heparin sodium, lorazepam, keppra, insulin, lactulose, colace, senna, albuterol, Tylenol, and bisacodyl.

The patient's laboratory results show some fluctuations in white blood cell count, hematocrit, platelet count, creatinine, total carbon dioxide, glucose, and liver enzymes. The arterial blood gas analysis indicates respiratory alkalosis with a pH of 7.49, elevated partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 30 mmHg, and normal oxygen saturation.

Radiology imaging, including a CT scan of the head and abdomen/pelvis, is pending.

Potential medical complications that can arise

   concern for giving D5W given CNS issues.
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Start D5W gently to decrease Na as pt is now NPO/NPG until at least
   Monday
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: Unclear if this represents true
   infection, but suspect at present this is likely not true pneumonia as
   she does not have a significant/new amount of sputum, no leukocytosis,
   and overall fever curve has improved. Chest x-ray also remains
   unimpressive for infection. Will have low threshold to initiate
   treatment, respiratory therapy completed a mini-BAL yesterday that
   showed no microorganisms or PMNs.
   - Bronchial washings performed by IP: culture pending, no micro seen
   # Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   -  Sent beta glucan pre and post Amp dosing to ascertain whether
   elevated level is related to abx
   #) Hypotension: Patient with transient hypotension overnight. This,
   coupled with her hypernatremia, borderline tachycardia, dry mucous
   membranes, all support volume depleted state. Monitoring closely for
   worsening sepsis. Will continue LR boluses to keep up urine output
   >40-50 cc/hour, SBP >90, and HR<100.
   # Peg: Required two attempts, being monitored closely for evidence of
   leak in stomach/peritonitis.
   - Gastrograffin study Monday
   - IP following

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely brain abscess. She is currently in the ICU for airway protection due to altered mental status. Her recent lab results show pancytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, and an elevated INR. She also has hypernatremia and hypotension. The patient's condition requires close monitoring, and various treatments and interventions are being implemented to manage her multiple complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1) Respiratory Failure: The patient's elevated respiratory rate may be secondary to her CNS process. Continuous monitoring of her respiratory status and assistance from respiratory therapy will be necessary.

2) Listeria Infection: The patient has Listeria bacteremia and meningitis, with a possible brain abscess. She is receiving appropriate antibiotic treatment with ampicillin and gentamicin. Close monitoring of her culture data and neurologic status is essential.

3) Pancytopenia: The patient has pancytopenia, which may be due to Imuran toxicity. Other possible causes include B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, or malignancy. Regular monitoring of blood counts and appropriate management will be necessary.

4) Elevated INR: The patient's elevated INR could be secondary to nutritional deficiencies or other underlying conditions. Continuous monitoring of coagulation parameters and administration of vitamin
