   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, with seizure overnight.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, now POD 2 from trach. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.
   -          Appreciate IP assistance. Currently doing well on pressure
   support [**7-25**]. Yesterday she was noted not to be breathing when
   spontaneous breathing trial was attempted. Will again complete SBT
   today.
   -          Will diurese as tolerated by blood pressure, but need to
   watch K and replete aggressively, given seizure at time of hypokalemia.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable.  If there are any changes
   in her imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, will
   re-consult neurosurgery. Given persistent fevers (although curve
   improving), TTE and TEE completed as noted (abnormal, but no definite
   abscess or vegetation). Overall fever curve is improving. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**] today is day 8.
   Following levels, which thus far have been at goal.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - Keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] (now IV given cannot use PEG).
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   - ID recommending repeat LP on tomorrow, will need to ensure that
   fungal, AFB, and modified cultures sent (eg to evaluate for Nocardia).
   - B-glucan repeated, pre- and post-ampicillin administration (over
   concerns that ampicillin could be causing elevated level). Will try to
   determine how lab samples may be distinguished, given they appear in
   OMR as having been collected at the same time.
   .
   #) Seizure: Patient with right facial twitching overnight felt to be
   seizure activity. This would be consistent in distribution given that
   her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left frontal area. It is possible
   that her hypokalemic state contributed to her seizure. Given lower HCT,
   concern was for bleed, however CT not supportive of this or of
   worsening edema/mass effect or other new pathology. Other consideration
   would be that seizures are less well controlled on keppra, given that
   phenytoin has been stopped and is likely now no longer therapeutic.
   Will discuss further with neurology if patient again has seizure
   without other possible explaniation. Checking electrolytes TID while
   diuresing, etc.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - This morning, HCT again down, CT ab/pelvis checked given recent
   procedure, no acute bleed upon prelim review.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **]-TID HCT
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, suspected to be secondary to nutritional
   deficiencies. Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well
   as FFP's at presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC
   appears to be less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this
   possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CT
s as well as coags every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have been trending downward,
   AST/ALT WNL currently. T. bili trending downward.
           -      Will continue to trend lipase, amylase, LFTs.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Improved with D5W, will continue to monitor again
   this PM, but given she cannot use her PEG yet, will likely need
   additional D5W (no worsening edema after D5W given).
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Start D5W gently to decrease Na as pt is now NPO/NPG until at least
   Monday
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. No PMNs upon
   bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to interpret.
   Additionally, fever curve improving. Will have low threshold to
   initiate treatment should fever curve, secretions, or WBC worsen.
   #) Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   -  Will attempt to determine which sample was pre and which was post
   ampicillin administration.
   #) PEG: Required two attempts, being monitored closely for evidence of
   leak in stomach/peritonitis. CT negative for acute change upon
   preliminary review this morning.
   - Gastrograffin study Monday
   - IP following
   ICU Care

   Holding TF until tomorrow (72 hrs) after PEG evaluated.
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin SS as needed

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease who presented with seizures and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. She underwent tracheostomy and is currently on pressure support. The patient experienced hypernatremia and received 1L D5W, with sodium levels at 145. She was given 10mg of IV lasix in the afternoon. A follow-up head CT showed no change. Neurological examination showed more organized brainstem function, PERRL, dolls eyes (although still asymmetric), some flexion tone of the upper extremities, but still not responsive to noxious stimuli. The patient had a seizure episode this morning with right-sided facial twitching, which was controlled with 1mg of ativan. Stat head CT is pending. Neurology recommended 600mg IV keppra load if seizures are not responsive to ativan. The patient's HCT is down to 21 and a CT abdomen/pelvis was performed at the same time as the head CT. The patient appears to be attempting to open her eyes at times but is not responsive to verbal or tactile stimuli. She grimaces minimally when her abdomen is pressed.

Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status. Her elevated respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.
2. Listeria

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient is currently intubated for airway protection and is on pressure support. She has been diagnosed with respiratory failure, Listeria infection, seizure, pancytopenia, elevated INR, elevated liver function tests, hypernatremia, and increased pigmentation. The patient's vital signs are stable, but she remains unresponsive to verbal or tactile stimuli. She has minimal grimace when her abdomen is pressed. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure could worsen due to her CNS process. Close monitoring of her respiratory rate and oxygen saturation is necessary.
2. Listeria Infection: The patient's Listeria infection may progress if not effectively treated. Monitoring of culture data and regular neurologic assessments are important.
3. Seizure: The patient may have recurrent seizures, especially if her electrolytes are not adequately managed. Continuous monitoring and prompt treatment of seizures are essential.
4. Pancytopenia: The patient's pancytopenia could worsen, leading to increased bleeding or infection risk. Regular monitoring of complete blood count (CBC) and appropriate management of hematologic abnormalities are crucial.
5. Elevated INR: The patient's elevated INR

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease who presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess. She is currently in the ICU and has been intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status. The patient's respiratory rate is elevated likely secondary to her CNS process. Her recent immunosuppressed state may have predisposed her to this condition.

The patient has been started on ampicillin and gentamicin for Listeria infection. The goal is to maintain a serum gentamicin level <2 for once-daily dosing. There are concerns about worsening mental status, and if there are any changes in her imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, neurosurgery consultation will be sought.

The patient's pancytopenia is consistent with Imuran toxicity, although other possibilities include B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. The patient's elevated INR is suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies. Listeria can present similarly to viral hepatitis, and the patient's elevated lipase today should be rechecked.

The patient has persistent hypernatremia, likely due to insensible losses from fevers, increased respiratory rate, and other insensible losses. She will need more free water repletion, but caution must be taken given her CNS issues. LR will be used for further fluid boluses.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently admitted to the ICU and has been experiencing several medical complications. 

1. Right-sided facial twitching: The patient experienced right-sided facial twitching in the afternoon, which did not break with 1 mg of ativan but broke with 2 mg. This could indicate seizures or seizure-like activity, and the neurology team recommended starting dilantin to control any potential seizure activity.

2. Transient hypotension after 3 mg of ativan: The patient experienced transient hypotension (low blood pressure) after receiving 3 mg of ativan. This can be a side effect of ativan and may require further evaluation and management.

3. Gentamicin dosing change: The patient's gentamicin dosing was changed from Q8H (every 8 hours) to Q12H (every 12 hours) due to high levels. This indicates that the previous dosing frequency may have resulted in excessive levels of gentamicin in the bloodstream, potentially leading to toxicity.

4. Gastrograffin study: The patient is scheduled to undergo a gastrograffin study, which is a diagnostic imaging procedure to assess the integrity of the gastrointestinal tract, particularly the esophagus and stomach. The purpose of this study may be to evaluate the patient's ability to swallow or identify any abnormalities in the digestive tract.

5. Allergies: The patient has no known drug allergies.

6. Infusions:

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. He was admitted to the ICU due to septic shock secondary to community-acquired pneumonia. The patient's current condition is stable, but there have been some complications and changes in treatment. The patient experienced right-sided facial twitching, which broke with 2 mg of lorazepam and lasted for about 3 minutes. Neurology recommended starting dilantin at a loading dose of 500 mg now, followed by 500 mg in the morning, and then 100 mg three times a day. The patient also had transient hypotension after receiving 3 mg of lorazepam, which responded to a 500 cc normal saline bolus. Gentamicin dosing was changed to once every 12 hours due to high levels. Additionally, a gastrograffin study is planned for either Monday or Tuesday, and the team will be informed by the physician.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Seizures: The patient experienced right-sided facial twitching, indicating a seizure-like event. The neurology team has recommended starting dilantin, which is an anticonvulsant medication used to prevent seizures. Therefore, the patient is at risk of recurrent seizures if the underlying cause is not addressed.

2. Hypotension: The patient experienced transient hypotension after receiving 3 mg of lorazepam. This could be due

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, with seizure overnight.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, now POD 4 from trach. Her elevated
   respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS process.  RSBI 72
   today.
   -          Appreciate IP assistance. Currently doing well on pressure
   support [**7-25**].
   -          Will diurese as tolerated by blood pressure, but need to
   watch K and replete aggressively, given seizure at time of hypokalemia;
   pt required 2 fluid boluses yesterday for low BP.
   -          SBT again today
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable.  If there are any changes
   in her imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, will
   re-consult neurosurgery. Given persistent fevers (although curve
   improving), TTE and TEE completed as noted (abnormal, but no definite
   abscess or vegetation). Overall fever curve is improving. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status.
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to Q 12.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data.
   - Keppra 1000 mg [**Hospital1 **] (now IV given cannot use PEG), added Dilantin
   given seizure activity, will discuss need for both agents.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role.
   - In event patient has decline or new imaging findings, will again
   address any benefits that decompression or drainage of possible
   empyema/abscess may have. Currently had no evidence of mass effect or
   significant edema on scans.
   - ID recommending repeat LP on today, will need to ensure that fungal,
   AFB, and modified cultures sent (eg to evaluate for Nocardia).
   - B-glucan repeated, pre- and post-ampicillin administration (over
   concerns that ampicillin could be causing elevated level). Will try to
   determine how lab samples may be distinguished, given they appear in
   OMR as having been collected at the same time.
   .
   #) Seizure: Patient with right facial twitching overnight felt to be
   seizure activity. This would be consistent in distribution given that
   her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left frontal area. It is possible
   that her hypokalemic state contributed to her seizure. Given lower HCT,
   concern was for bleed, however CT not supportive of this or of
   worsening edema/mass effect or other new pathology. Other consideration
   would be that seizures are less well controlled on keppra, given that
   phenytoin has been stopped and is likely now no longer therapeutic.
   Will discuss further with neurology if patient again has seizure
   without other possible explanation. Checking electrolytes TID while
   diuresing, etc
   - F/U Neuro recs re: anticonvulsants
 Keppra 1500 [**Hospital1 **], Dilantin 100
   TID today, [**Hospital1 **] tomorrow, QD on Wednesday, then stop Dilantin
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with pancytopenia
   is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other possibilities being B12
   or folate deficiency, viral process, and less likely malignancy. B12
   and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - This morning, HCT again down, CT ab/pelvis checked given recent
   procedure, no acute bleed upon prelim review.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Follow [**Hospital1 **]-TID HCTs.
   .
   #) Elevated INR: Stable, suspected to be secondary to nutritional
   deficiencies. Patient has received multiple doses of vitamin K as well
   as FFPs at presentation. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC
   appears to be less likely, but still will continue to monitor for this
   possibility.
   - Continuing to follow head CTs as well as coags every other day.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have been trending downward,
   AST/ALT WNL currently. T. bili trending downward.
           -      Will continue to trend lipase, amylase, LFTs.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Improved with D5W, will continue to monitor, but
   given she cannot use her PEG yet, will likely need additional D5W (no
   worsening edema after D5W given).
   Given hypernatremia and hyperchloremia, will use LR for further fluid
   boluses.
   - Start D5W gently to decrease Na as pt is now NPO/NPG until at least
   Monday
   - Will continue to trend sodium, re-check this evening.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Gram negative rods in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. No PMNs upon
   bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to interpret.
   Additionally, fever curve improving. Will have low threshold to
   initiate treatment should fever curve, secretions, or WBC worsen.
   #) Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   -  Will attempt to determine which sample was pre and which was post
   ampicillin administration.
   #) PEG: Required two attempts, being monitored closely for evidence of
   leak in stomach/peritonitis. CT negative for acute change upon
   preliminary review this morning.
   - Gastrograffin study Monday
   - IP following
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Holding TF until PEG evaluated.
   Glycemic Control:  Insulin SS as needed

   Multi Lumen - [**2124-9-15**] 01:38 PM

   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:  Chlorhexidine/Head of bed elevated

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely a Listeria brain abscess. She has been intubated for airway protection and is currently on pressure support. The patient is also experiencing respiratory failure, and her elevated respiratory rate is likely due to her CNS process. She has had several episodes of hypotension, requiring fluid boluses. The patient has pancytopenia, which is consistent with Imuran toxicity, and her INR is elevated but stable, suspected to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies. Her liver function tests are stable, and she has improved hypernatremia. There is also a question of increased pigmentation, which could be related to Addison's disease or hemochromatosis. The patient has Gram-negative rods in her sputum, but no evidence of infection. She has a positive beta-glucan, which may indicate a fungal infection. The patient recently underwent a PEG placement, which required two attempts and is being closely monitored for evidence of leak or peritonitis.

Based on the provided information, the patient is a 58-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of generalized weakness and shortness of breath. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and coronary artery disease.

Upon admission, the patient's vital signs were as follows: temperature 36.7°C, heart rate 73 bpm, blood pressure 100/51 mmHg, respiratory rate 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. The patient was noted to have decreased breath sounds in the left lung base and diffuse wheezing throughout the right lung. 

Initial laboratory results showed leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14.6 K/uL, elevated blood glucose levels ranging from 92 to 108 mg/dL, and hyponatremia with a sodium level of 120 mEq/L. The patient also had thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 86 K/uL.

Chest X-ray revealed bilateral infiltrates consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The patient was started on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 310 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fractional inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

During the course of hospitalization, the patient's condition has fluctuated. There have been episodes of subtle head movement and twitching

Summary: The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure, and subsequent cultures revealed Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely brain abscess. She has undergone tracheostomy and is currently intubated for airway protection. Her respiratory rate is elevated, likely due to her central nervous system (CNS) process. She is on CPAP/PSV with FiO2 of 40%. Her recent labs show pancytopenia, which may be consistent with Imuran toxicity. She also has elevated liver function tests (LFTs) and an elevated INR, which could be secondary to nutritional deficiencies. She has hypernatremia, which has improved with D5W. There is a question of increased pigmentation, possibly due to medication or an underlying condition. Her imaging studies show stable head CTs with no evidence of mass effect or significant edema. She has a positive beta-glucan, which could indicate a fungal infection, particularly given her recent immunosuppression. She is being monitored closely for evidence of a leak in the stomach/peritonitis following the placement of a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube. The patient's current plan includes continuing seizure prophylaxis with Keppra and Dilantin, monitoring for any new neurological changes, and repeating LP to send modified cultures.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. She underwent tracheostomy placement and is currently intubated for airway protection. Her mental status remains altered, and she has intermittent movements that could be consistent with seizures. She is being treated with ampicillin and gentamicin for the Listeria infection. Her pancytopenia is stable, but she has elevated coagulation studies, possibly due to systemic absorption of subcutaneous heparin. Her liver function tests are stable, and she has hypernatremia, which is being managed with maintenance fluids. There is a question of increased skin pigmentation, and she has a positive beta-glucan, suggesting a possible fungal infection. She recently underwent percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) placement. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. There is a plan to transition her to breathing trials and re-check ABG afterwards, with a possible transition to trach mask if tolerated.
2. Listeria infection: The patient has Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely brain abscess. She is being treated with appropriate antibiotics, but monitoring for any changes in mental status or new neurological deficits is essential.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 58-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU on [date] with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient has a history of hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease. Upon admission, the patient was found to be hypotensive and tachycardic, with low oxygen saturation. Initial laboratory results showed elevated troponin levels, indicating possible myocardial infarction. The patient was started on IV fluids and medications to stabilize blood pressure and heart rate.

Over the course of the hospital stay, the patient's condition has fluctuated. There have been multiple episodes of hypotension and tachycardia, requiring adjustments in medication dosages. The patient's respiratory status has also been concerning, with intermittent hypoxia and increased work of breathing. Mechanical ventilation was initiated to support the patient's breathing.

Neurological assessment revealed a decreased level of consciousness, with the patient not fully responsive. Imaging studies, including a head CT scan, showed no signs of intracranial bleeding or significant abnormalities. An EEG was ordered to further evaluate the patient's mental status changes.

In terms of fluid balance, the patient has received a significant amount of IV fluids, with ongoing losses through urine and stool. The patient's weight has decreased by approximately 1 kg since admission.

Laboratory results indicate an elevated white blood cell count and slightly decreased platelet count. Other lab values, such as kidney function and electroly

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, with continued activity concerning for seizures.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, and underwent tracheostomy on
   [**2124-9-22**]. Her elevated respiratory rate is likely secondary to her CNS
   process.  RSBI 77 today.
   -          Appreciate IP assistance. Currently doing well on pressure
   support [**4-24**], so will transition to breathing trial and re-check ABG
   afterwards, with transition to trach mask if possible.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable.  If there are any changes
   in her imaging concerning for worsening edema or bleeding, will
   re-consult neurosurgery. Given persistent fevers (although curve
   improving), TTE and TEE completed as noted (abnormal, but no definite
   abscess or vegetation). Overall fever curve is improving. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status, however there is concern for
   intermittent seizure activity (twitching of right cheek,
   opening/closing of mouth, moving of head).
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to Q 12. (Today is day 10)
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - Will continue to follow culture data, and plan to repeat LP today
   after CT head, to send for fungal, AFB, modified cultures (to exclude
   Nocardia).
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role (once can give PO
s again)
   - B-glucan repeated, pre- and post-ampicillin administration (over
   concerns that ampicillin could be causing elevated level). Will look
   for change in level (since both samples timed alike).
   .
   #) Seizure: Patient has had intermittent movements that could be
   consistent with seizures, such as right facial twitching, mouth
   movement, and head shaking. This would be consistent in distribution
   given that her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left frontal area. It
   is difficult to say if these activities have been seizures, and they
   have stopped after administration of ativan.
   - Requested 24 EEG monitoring to assess if activities correlate with
   EEG evidence of seizures (EEG had not suggestive of non-convulsive
   status)
   - Increased Keppra to 1500 mg [**Hospital1 **], Dilantin 100 [**Hospital1 **] today, then 100
   daily, then stop
   - Repeat head CT today.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Stable. Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with
   pancytopenia is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other
   possibilities being B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less
   likely malignancy. B12 and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - This morning, HCT again down, CT ab/pelvis checked given recent
   procedure, no acute bleed upon prelim review.
   - Continue to monitor [**Hospital1 1174**], transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   .
   #) Elevated Coagulation Studies: PTT increased today, suspect likely
   secondary to systemic absorption of subcutaneous heparin. Her elevated
   INR had been felt to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies and liver
   disease. Per hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be less
   likely, but still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Following [**Last Name (LF) 1174**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] need to ensure PTT is lower (eg <40) prior to
   LP today.
   - Holding SQ heparin today.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable. RUQ consistent with liver disease, no
   other concerning pathology (no ductal dilation or gall bladder
   abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have been trending downward,
   AST/ALT WNL currently. T. bili trending downward.
           -      Will continue to [**First Name3 (LF) 1174**] lipase, amylase, LFTs.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Maintanence fluids with D5W, since cannot use PEG
   yet. Will switch to FW flushes once PEG is usable.
   - Will continue to [**Location (un) 1174**] sodium, re-check this evening.
   .
   #) Question of increased pigmentation: Family provided history of
   darkening skin pigment over last months to years. This also was
   reported in her outpatient visits with her gastroenterologist (at that
   time, her T. Bili was 23). Appreciate dermatology input on this matter
   as well. No evidence of adrenal disease (Addison
s, or
   hemachromatosis).
   #) Acinetobacter in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. Fevers have resolved.
   No PMNs upon bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to
   interpret, but suspect colonization.
   - Contact precautions.
   .

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. She underwent tracheostomy and is currently on invasive ventilation. The patient has several ongoing medical issues, including respiratory failure, Listeria infection, seizures, pancytopenia, elevated coagulation studies, elevated liver function tests, hypernatremia, and potential increased pigmentation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is on invasive ventilation due to airway protection in an altered mental state. There is an ongoing effort to wean her off the ventilator and transition to a tracheostomy mask.
2. Listeria infection: The patient has bacteremia, meningitis, and a suspected brain abscess caused by Listeria. She is being treated with ampicillin and gentamicin, and further cultures and tests are pending.
3. Seizures: The patient has had intermittent movements that could be consistent with seizures. EEG monitoring has been requested to assess if these activities correlate with EEG evidence of seizures.
4. Pancytopenia: The patient has a decrease in white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets. The cause is suspected to be Imuran toxicity, but other possibilities include B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and malignancy.

s have been stable. TTE and TEE completed as

s again)

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease who presented with seizure, Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. She underwent tracheostomy and is currently on a tracheostomy mask, remaining obtunded. The patient has respiratory failure, Listeria infection, seizure activity, pancytopenia, elevated coagulation studies, elevated liver function tests, hypernatremia, colonization of Acinetobacter in sputum, positive beta-glucan, and extensive peripheral edema.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's altered mental status and airway protection require ongoing respiratory support.
2. Listeria infection: The patient has bacteremia, meningitis, and a brain abscess caused by Listeria. This infection needs to be treated aggressively with appropriate antibiotics.
3. Seizure activity: The patient has intermittent movements that could be consistent with seizures, especially considering the presence of a presumed abscess in the left frontal area.
4. Pancytopenia: The patient has a low white blood cell count, red blood cell count, and platelet count, which may be due to Imuran toxicity or other causes. Close monitoring and possible transfusion are necessary.
5. Elevated coagulation studies: The patient's PTT is elevated, possibly due to systemic absorption of subcutaneous heparin.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient underwent tracheostomy and has been on a tracheostomy mask. She is currently on ampicillin and gentamicin for the infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient was intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status. She underwent tracheostomy on [**2124-9-22**]. She has been doing well on the tracheostomy mask, but there is a potential for continued respiratory failure if she does not wean off the ventilator or if she develops any complications such as pneumonia or tracheostomy site infection.

2. Listeria Bacteremia and Meningitis/Encephalitis/Abscess: The patient has been diagnosed with Listeria bacteremia and meningitis, with a likely brain abscess. The infection is caused by Listeria monocytogenes, which is more common in immunocompromised individuals. The patient's recent immunosuppressed state due to treatment for autoimmune hepatitis may have predisposed her to this infection. Serial head CT scans have been stable, but there is a potential for worsening of the infection leading to further neurological complications.

3. Intermittent Seiz

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, doing well on trach mask, but remaining obtunded.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, and underwent tracheostomy on
   [**2124-9-22**]. She has done well on trach mask for over 48 hours now, with
   a re-assuring ABG. No significant secretions to suggest pneumonia.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable. TTE and TEE completed as
   noted (abnormal, but no definite abscess or vegetation. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status, however there is concern for
   intermittent seizure activity (twitching of right cheek,
   opening/closing of mouth, moving of head).
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to 120 mg Q 12. (Today is day 12)
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - LP this morning to send for fungal, AFB, modified cultures (to
   exclude Nocardia), given PTT is normal this morning after holding
   subcutaneous heparin.
   - Neuro checks q2H
   - Lactulose being given in event that hepatic encephalopathy was
   playing role (once can give PO
s again)
   - Will discuss B-glucan results with ID team, await results of LP,
   discuss empiric treatment and further sampling of mass.
   - MR with contrast and MR spectroscopy to be completed to evaluate for
   other etiologies of frontal mass, as per discussion with neurology team
   after interdisciplinary conference, there is concern that her mass is
   not completely consistent with a listeria abscess. MR spectroscopy
   could help evaluate for lymphoma.
   .
   #) Seizure: No abnormal movements noted over last 48 hours (last 24 on
   EEG). Prior to that time, patient has had intermittent movements that
   could be consistent with seizures, such as right facial twitching,
   mouth movement, and head shaking. This would be consistent in
   distribution given that her mass (presumed abscess) is in the left
   frontal area. It is difficult to say if these activities have been
   seizures, and they  have stopped after administration of ativan.
   - Will follow up results of 24 hr EEG.
   - Increased Keppra to 1500 mg [**Hospital1 **].
   - MR to be completed today.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Stable. Per hematology consult, elevated MCV with
   pancytopenia is consistent with Imuran toxicity, with other
   possibilities being B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, and less
   likely malignancy. B12 and folate were WNL.
   Concern had been for hemolysis, however upon re-evaluation by
   hematology, smear was not consistent with this (FDP 10-40, haptoglobin
   was <20). No new medications or clear offending medications upon review
   of list.
   - Continue to monitor trend, transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   .
   #) Elevated Coagulation Studies: Stable, PTT down after holding
   subcutaneous heparin, suspect this was secondary to systemic absorption
   of subcutaneous heparin. Her elevated INR had been felt to be secondary
   to nutritional deficiencies and liver disease. Per hematology and
   laboratory values, DIC appears to be less likely, but still will
   continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Holding SQ heparin today until after LP, then will re-start at [**Hospital1 **]
   dosing.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable, with some day-to-day variation. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have
   been trending downward, AST/ALT WNL currently.
           -      Will continue to trend lipase, amylase, LFTs.
   -          Some records obtained, continuing to obtain remainder from
   [**Doctor Last Name 918**] (fax sent again with husband
s consent).
   -          Records from [**Location (un) 841**] pending (faxed request x 2)
   .
   #) Hypernatremia: Resolved. Continue free water flushes at current
   rate.
   .
   #) Acinetobacter in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. Fevers have resolved.
   No PMNs upon bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to
   interpret, but suspect colonization.
   - Contact precautions, will follow up repeat sputum culture (which has
   acinetibacter)
   .
   #) Positive beta-glucan.  [**Month (only) 11**] be indicator of fungal infection,
   particularly given recent immunosuppression.
   - ID recs: difficult to interpret in context of abx, recommend
   rechecking, if positive could empirically tx
   -  Will discuss further with ID.
   .
   #) FEN: Will attempt to gently diurese today given extensive peripheral
   edema as tolerated by BP.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease who presented with a seizure, diagnosed with Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess. She has been intubated for airway protection and underwent tracheostomy. The patient remains obtunded. Her recent immune-suppressed state due to treatment for autoimmune hepatitis may have predisposed her to infection. Serial head CT scans have been stable, but there are concerns about intermittent seizure activity. The patient has been receiving ampicillin and gentamicin, and a lumbar puncture was performed to send for fungal, AFB, modified cultures, and to exclude Nocardia. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is on tracheostomy and intubated, which puts her at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess: The patient has been diagnosed with Listeria bacteremia and meningitis, and there is a concern for a brain abscess. This can lead to further neurological complications.
3. Seizure: The patient has intermittent movements that could be consistent with seizures, potentially due to the brain abscess.
4. Pancytopenia: The patient has stable pancytopenia, which could be due to Imuran toxicity or other causes like B12 or folate deficiency, viral process, or malignancy.
5.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease who presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient underwent tracheostomy and is currently on a tracheostomy mask with reassuring ABG results. She is being weaned off FiO2 and has shown improvement in her fever curve and hemodynamics.

The patient has been on ampicillin and gentamicin since September 17th, with gentamicin levels adjusted to 120 mg Q12H. The anticipated length of treatment is expected to be several weeks, depending on the results of the CSF culture.

A lumbar puncture was performed, showing no organisms or PMNs in the CSF, and the cryptococcal antigen was negative. An MRI with contrast is being completed this morning, along with MR spectroscopy to evaluate for other etiologies of the frontal mass, as per discussion with the neurology team. There is concern that the mass may not be consistent with a Listeria abscess, and MR spectroscopy could help evaluate for lymphoma. The hematology team will comment on the possibility of lymphoma.

The patient's WBC and HCT are trending downward, which is concerning given that she has been off immunosuppressive agents for over two weeks. This may indicate pancytopenia, and a bone marrow biopsy is being considered for further evaluation

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient underwent tracheostomy and has been on a tracheostomy mask. She has been intubated for respiratory failure and is currently weaning off FiO2. The patient has been on antibiotics for Listeria infection, but there is a concern for possible fungal infection as well. She has shown improvement in her condition, with decreasing WBC count and no organisms seen in the CSF culture. However, there are still concerns about her mental status and the possibility of seizures. The patient has pancytopenia, which is concerning given her recent immunosuppressive treatment. There are also elevated coagulation studies, but they seem to be stable now. The patient's liver function tests are slightly elevated, and there are attempts to obtain records from previous hospitalizations. The patient has Acinetobacter in her sputum, but it is unclear if it is an infection or colonization. Finally, the patient has a positive beta-glucan, which could indicate a fungal infection, but imaging has remained stable and other indicators of infection have improved.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure due to the patient's altered mental status and need for airway protection.
2. Listeria infection causing bacteremia, meningitis

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of pancytopenia, likely due to azathioprine, as well as a neurologic condition with poor prognosis. The patient has been experiencing multiple medical complications since admission. These include blood noted from tracheostomy, erosions seen on bronchoscopy, and a CT scan ruling out tracheoinnominate fistula. An MRI shows abscesses in the right frontal and parietal regions, with new areas of enhancement seen in the right frontal lobe and right caudate head. EEG results indicate severe encephalopathy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Tracheoinnominate fistula: Although initially suspected, a CT scan ruled out this condition.
2. Tracheoesophageal fistula: The CTA neck showed no evidence of this.
3. Abscesses: The MRI revealed abscesses in the right frontal and parietal regions, indicating a possible central nervous system infection.
4. Encephalopathy: The EEG results indicate severe encephalopathy, suggesting impaired brain function.
5. Pancytopenia: The patient has pancytopenia, which is a reduction in the number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. This can lead to anemia, increased risk of infection, and bleeding problems.
6. Neurological deterioration: The patient's neurologic condition is worsening, as evidenced

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease.
- She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and brain abscess.
- She underwent tracheostomy and has been on a tracheal mask for over 72 hours without significant secretions or pneumonia.
- The patient experienced hemoptysis yesterday, but no further bleeding has been noted. A CT angiography ruled out a tracheo-innominate fistula.
- Her recent immunosuppressed state may have predisposed her to infection.
- Serial head CT scans have been stable.
- She has been on ampicillin and gentamicin since September 17th, and the dosing of gentamicin was adjusted based on levels.
- The expected treatment duration is several weeks, depending on CSF culture results, final MRI read, and input from ID and neurology teams.
- A lumbar puncture supports the clearing of infection, especially with the improvement in fever curve and other hemodynamics.
- Monitoring culture data is negative for growth, and Cryptococcal antigen is negative.
- There is a concern for possible CNS lymphoma, and hematology has been re-consulted for further evaluation, including flow cytometry and bone marrow biopsy.
- The patient's pancytopenia is stable, and the possibility of a hematologic malignancy is being considered.
- Her elevated coagulation

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is a 60-year-old woman with a complex medical history. She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient underwent a tracheostomy and has been on a tracheostomy mask. She is also experiencing respiratory failure, pancytopenia, elevated coagulation studies, elevated liver function tests, colonization of Acinetobacter in sputum, and positive beta-glucan indicating a possible fungal infection.

The patient's neurological status is concerning, with diminished mental status and intermittent seizure-like activity. Imaging studies, such as a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and meningitis, are present. The patient has been treated with antibiotics (ampicillin and gentamicin) for the Listeria infection, and the levels of these medications have been adjusted accordingly.

The patient's blood counts are decreasing, indicating pancytopenia. This could be due to the immunosuppressive agents she has been receiving for autoimmune hepatitis. There is concern for a hematologic malignancy, and a bone marrow biopsy may be necessary for further evaluation.

The patient's coagulation studies show elevated levels, which have stabilized after discontinuing subcutaneous heparin. The elevated liver function tests may be secondary to liver disease, and the patient's history of autoimmune hepatitis could contribute to this.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, doing well on trach mask, with marked improvement in
   mental status overnight.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, and underwent tracheostomy on
   [**2124-9-22**]. She has done well on trach mask for over several days now,
   with a re-assuring ABGs. No significant secretions to suggest
   pneumonia. Continuing to wean FiO2, currently at 35%. She had had
   episode of hemoptysis, however bronchoscopy and CTA re-assuring;
   bleeding was likely due to small site of erosion.
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Overnight with marked improvement in mental status
able to follow some
   commands, attempted to speak. Based on MRI yesterday, there is concern
   that patient may have another process such as neoplasm or fungal
   infection, or endocarditis that continues to seed her CSF.
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable. TTE and TEE completed as
   noted (abnormal, but no definite abscess or vegetation. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status, however there is concern for
   intermittent seizure activity (twitching of right cheek,
   opening/closing of mouth, moving of head).
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to 120 mg Q 12. (Today is day 14). Length of
   treatment (given question of abscess, Bacteremia, meningitis),
   anticipate several weeks ([**1-24**] or more), will depend on results of CSF
   culture results, final read of MRI, ID and neurology input.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - LP completed [**9-28**], supports picture of clearing infection (decreased
   WBC, no organisms), especially given improvement in fever curve and
   remainder of hemodynamics. Sent for fungal, AFB, modified cultures (to
   exclude Nocardia). Cryptococcal antigen negative. Monitoring culture
   data which is NGTD.
   - Flow cytometry of CSF [**Month/Day (4) 1327**], MR [**First Name (Titles) 1328**] [**Last Name (Titles) 1327**].
   - Given question of fungal infection in setting of new lesions and
   elevated beta-glucan, initiated empiric anti-fungal coverage, sent off
   fungal cultures. Neurosurgery re-consulted to discuss sampling of brain
   lesions. Cardiology also involved as first TEE was not entirely normal,
   to re-evaluate if patient has vegetation or abscess that could account
   for findings (as in this event, would less likely need brain biopsy).
   Neurology to see patient over the weekend and assist with further
   prognosis, work-up, etc. Input greatly appreciated.
   - Aprpeciate hematology assistance with possible marrow biopsy to
   further evaluate for possible fungal infection in setting of (+)
   B-glucan.
   - Keppra 1500 mg [**Hospital1 **] for seizure prophylaxis, no seizure activity noted
   on EEG.
   - PT/OT consults over next 1-2 days.
   - Speech consult for PMV.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: WBC and HCT improved today, however platelets slightly
   down. Patient has been off of all immunosuppressive agents for over two
   weeks, as these were felt to be the most likely etiology (other
   possibilities included stress of acute infection, viral process). Labs
   and smear have not been consistent with hemolysis.
   Given that immunosuppressive agents could mask a hematologic
   malignancy, which is now more evident after they have been held (LDH
   also elevated), and given concern for possible CNS lymphoma, hematology
   was re-consulted to comment on utility of bone marrow biopsy for
   further evaluation, also in setting of question of fungal infection.
   - SPEP [**Hospital1 1327**], retic count demonstrated marrow is responding
   - Appreciate hematology assistance, flow cytometry sent, will continue
   to consider bone marrow biopsy.
   - Continue to monitor [**Hospital1 1174**], transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   .
   #) Elevated Coagulation Studies: Stable. Her elevated INR had been felt
   to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies and liver disease. Per
   hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be less likely, but
   still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Appreciate hematology assistance. Pneumoboots for now for DVT
   prophylaxis, then likely [**Hospital1 **] heparin.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable, some slightly up today. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have
   been trending downward, AST/ALT WNL currently. Records have been
   obtained and are present in back of patient
s chart from work up in
   [**State 951**]. Many attempts have been made to obtain records from [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in
   [**Location (un) 841**], CA, where patient was admitted with what sounds like near
   fulminant hepatic failure (T. Bili of 23, transaminases in thousands).
   - Will continue to monitor [**Last Name (LF) 1174**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] need to involve liver team if
   laboratory values continue to worsen.
      .
   #) Acinetobacter in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. Fevers have resolved.
   No PMNs upon bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to
   interpret, but suspect colonization.
   - Contact precautions.
   .
   #) FEN: Again, will attempt to gently diurese today given extensive
   peripheral edema as tolerated by BP.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess. She underwent tracheostomy and has been on a tracheostomy mask, showing marked improvement in mental status overnight. The patient's respiratory status is stable, but there are concerns about potential complications such as fungal infection or endocarditis. Listeria was noted in blood and CSF cultures, and she has been on appropriate antibiotics. There is also concern for possible CNS lymphoma and pancytopenia. The patient's coagulation studies are elevated, but stable, and liver function tests are slightly up. There is an attempt to obtain records from a previous admission where the patient had near fulminant hepatic failure. The patient has been diagnosed with ileus and is receiving IV lasix for diuresis. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Fungal infection: Given the new lesions on MRI, there is concern for a fungal infection. Empiric anti-fungal coverage has been initiated, and cultures are pending.
2. Endocarditis: The patient's TEE was abnormal, but no definite vegetation or abscess was seen. Further evaluation is needed to rule out endocarditis.
3. Pancytopenia: The patient's WBC and HCT have improved, but platelets are slightly down.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with a seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. She underwent tracheostomy and is currently intubated for airway protection. The patient has shown improvement in her condition, with no significant secretions to suggest pneumonia. However, she experienced hemoptysis and blood around her trach site, which was likely due to an erosion. The patient is being weaned off FiO2 and her ABG is reassuring. 

The patient also has pancytopenia, with stable cell counts today. There is concern for possible CNS lymphoma, and a bone marrow biopsy has been recommended. The patient's elevated coagulation studies are stable, and she has an increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment. Her elevated liver function tests are overall stable, but there may be a need to involve the liver team if laboratory values continue to worsen. 

The patient has a positive beta-glucan, which may indicate a fungal infection, but imaging has remained stable and all other indicators of infection have improved. She is also being monitored for possible DVT and stress ulcers. The patient's current medications include ambisome, Keppra, gentamicin, Ativan, fentanyl, lansoprazole, insulin sliding scale, lactulose, col

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease, presenting with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post tracheostomy. She is intubated for airway protection and has been doing well on trach mask for over 72 hours. The patient has active type/cross as well as additional peripheral IVs in event of additional significant bleeding.

The patient's respiratory failure is being managed by weaning FiO2, currently at 35%. Hemoptysis occurred yesterday, and bronchoscopy demonstrated an erosion that was felt to likely be the source of her bleeding. A computed tomography angiography (CTA) was negative for fistula. No further bleeding has been noted.

The patient has been diagnosed with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), meningitis, sepsis, severe (with organ dysfunction), and anemia, hemolytic. Her laboratory results show leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, elevated liver enzymes, coagulation studies, and lactate levels. The patient also has elevated D-dimer levels, indicating possible disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

There are concerns regarding the possibility of fungal infection, as indicated by a positive beta-glucan test. However, imaging has remained stable, and all other indicators of infection have improved. Antifungal coverage has been started in light of

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 60 year old female with past medical history of autoimmune
   disease, who presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia,
   meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess, status-post
   tracheostomy, doing well on trach mask, with marked improvement in
   mental status overnight.
   .
   #) Respiratory failure: Patient intubated for airway protection in
   setting of altered mental status, and underwent tracheostomy on
   [**2124-9-22**]. She has done well on trach mask for over several days now,
   with a re-assuring ABGs. No significant secretions to suggest
   pneumonia. Continuing to wean FiO2, currently at 35%. She had had
   episode of hemoptysis, however bronchoscopy and CTA re-assuring;
   bleeding was likely due to small site of erosion.
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated
   - PMV today
   .
   #) Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess and
   resultant mental status:
   Overnight with marked improvement in mental status
able to follow some
   commands, attempted to speak. Based on MRI yesterday, there is concern
   that patient may have another process such as neoplasm or fungal
   infection, or endocarditis that continues to seed her CSF.
   Listeria noted in blood and CSF cultures from [**9-15**] and [**9-16**]
   respectively. Her recently immuno-suppressed state secondary to
   treatment for auto-immune hepatitis may have pre-disposed her to
   infection. Serial head CT
s have been stable. TTE and TEE completed as
   noted (abnormal, but no definite abscess or vegetation. EEG was not
   suggestive of convulsive status, however there is concern for
   intermittent seizure activity (twitching of right cheek,
   opening/closing of mouth, moving of head).
   - Ampicillin and gentimicin were started on [**9-17**]. Following levels,
   adjusted gent dosing to 120 mg Q 12. (Today is day 15). Length of
   treatment (given question of abscess, Bacteremia, meningitis),
   anticipate several weeks ([**1-24**] or more), will depend on results of CSF
   culture results, final read of MRI, ID and neurology input.
   - Appreciate ID and neurology input.
   - LP completed [**9-28**], supports picture of clearing infection (decreased
   WBC, no organisms), especially given improvement in fever curve and
   remainder of hemodynamics. Sent for fungal, AFB, modified cultures (to
   exclude Nocardia). Cryptococcal antigen negative. Monitoring culture
   data which is NGTD.
   - Flow cytometry of CSF [**Month/Day (4) 1327**], MR [**First Name (Titles) 1328**] [**Last Name (Titles) 1327**].
   - Given question of fungal infection in setting of new lesions and
   elevated beta-glucan, initiated empiric anti-fungal coverage, sent off
   fungal cultures. Neurosurgery re-consulted to discuss sampling of brain
   lesions. Cardiology also involved as first TEE was not entirely normal,
   to re-evaluate if patient has vegetation or abscess that could account
   for findings (as in this event, would less likely need brain biopsy).
   Neurology to see patient over the weekend and assist with further
   prognosis, work-up, etc. Input greatly appreciated.
   - Aprpeciate hematology assistance with possible marrow biopsy to
   further evaluate for possible fungal infection in setting of (+)
   B-glucan.
   - Keppra 1500 mg [**Hospital1 **] for seizure prophylaxis, no seizure activity noted
   on EEG.
   - PT/OT consults over next 1-2 days.
   - Speech consult for PMV.
   .
   #) Pancytopenia: Ongoing issue. WBC improved, Hct down. Patient has
   been off of all immunosuppressive agents for over two weeks, as these
   were felt to be the most likely etiology (other possibilities included
   stress of acute infection, viral process). Labs and smear have not been
   consistent with hemolysis.
   Given that immunosuppressive agents could mask a hematologic
   malignancy, which is now more evident after they have been held (LDH
   also elevated), and given concern for possible CNS lymphoma, hematology
   was re-consulted to comment on utility of bone marrow biopsy for
   further evaluation, also in setting of question of fungal infection.
   - SPEP [**Hospital1 1327**], retic count demonstrated marrow is responding
   - Appreciate hematology assistance, flow cytometry sent, will continue
   to consider bone marrow biopsy.
   - Continue to monitor [**Hospital1 1174**], transfuse if HCT <21-22 or symptoms.
   - TPMT returned positive, consistent with heterozyogous state, which
   suggests increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment.
   - Transfuse today if Hct < 21
   .
   #) Elevated Coagulation Studies: Stable. Her elevated INR had been felt
   to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies and liver disease. Per
   hematology and laboratory values, DIC appears to be less likely, but
   still will continue to monitor for this possibility.
   - Appreciate hematology assistance. Pneumoboots for now for DVT
   prophylaxis, then likely [**Hospital1 **] heparin.
   .
   #) Elevated LFTs: Overall stable, some slightly up today. RUQ
   consistent with liver disease, no other concerning pathology (no ductal
   dilation or gall bladder abnormalities noted. Amylase and lipase have
   been trending downward, AST/ALT WNL currently. Records have been
   obtained and are present in back of patient
s chart from work up in
   [**State 951**]. Many attempts have been made to obtain records from [**Doctor Last Name 918**] in
   [**Location (un) 841**], CA, where patient was admitted with what sounds like near
   fulminant hepatic failure (T. Bili of 23, transaminases in thousands).
   - Will continue to monitor [**Last Name (LF) 1174**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] need to involve liver team if
   laboratory values continue to worsen.
      .
   #) Acinetobacter in sputum: No consolidation, leukocytosis, or
   significant secretions to suggest true infection. Fevers have resolved.
   No PMNs upon bronchial [**Last Name (LF) 1119**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] makes culture data difficult to
   interpret, but suspect colonization.
   - Contact precautions.
   .
   #) Dilated loops bowel: Had large BM yesterday, abd soft but distended,
   non-tender.
   - Aggressive bowel regimen
   - Follow with daily KUB, serial exams
   .
   #) ? RLL infiltrate: Seen on CXR today, possible early PNA. Pt has been
   Afebrile, normal WBC but 6% bands today.
   - If febrile, or clinical deterioration, start abx for HAP
   - Sputum cx
   .
   #) FEN: Again, will attempt to gently diurese today given extensive
   peripheral edema as tolerated by BP and heart rate.

Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease, who presented with seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. She underwent tracheostomy and has been doing well on tracheostomy mask, with marked improvement in mental status overnight. The patient is currently being treated with ampicillin and gentamicin for Listeria infection, which may continue for several weeks depending on the results of CSF culture and final read of MRI. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status. She is currently on tracheostomy mask and weaning FiO2 as tolerated.
2. Listeria bacteremia and meningitis/encephalitis/abscess: The patient has shown marked improvement in mental status, but further treatment and monitoring are required.
3. Pancytopenia: The patient's white blood cell count (WBC) has improved, but hemoglobin (Hct) levels are down. There is ongoing evaluation for possible hematologic malignancy or fungal infection.
4. Elevated coagulation studies: The patient's elevated INR appears to be secondary to nutritional deficiencies and liver disease. Monitoring for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is ongoing.
5. Elevated liver function tests (LFTs): The patient's LFTs

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of recent symptoms and conditions, including suspected endocarditis, neurological improvement, and potential complications such as aortic dissection or intracranial hemorrhage. The patient's vital signs are stable, but they show signs of fluid overload with peripheral edema. Laboratory results indicate electrolyte imbalances, specifically low potassium and magnesium levels, as well as elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels, suggesting possible renal dysfunction. The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, proton pump inhibitors, diuretics, and other ICU medications. The patient's recent imaging studies show findings consistent with previous areas of abnormal diffusion but no new findings. The patient's overall condition appears to be improving, with ongoing evaluation for endocarditis and monitoring of gentamicin levels.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Endocarditis: The patient's clinical presentation and imaging findings suggest a possible diagnosis of endocarditis. This condition can lead to serious complications such as heart valve damage, heart failure, abscess formation, or embolic events.
2. Aortic dissection: The presence of aortic root dilation or involvement in the patient's medical history increases the risk of aortic dissection. This condition is a life-threatening emergency that requires immediate surgical intervention.
3. Intracranial hemorrhage: The patient's neurological symptoms and imaging findings may raise concerns about the possibility of an intracranial hemorrhage.

The patient underwent tracheostomy and has been doing well on tracheostomy, with marked improvement in mental status overnight.

The potential medical complications that can arise from this information include:

2. EEG was not suggestive of convulsive status, however, there is concern for intermittent seizure activity. Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with seizure, found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient underwent tracheostomy and is currently on a tracheostomy mask. She has hemoptysis but no further bleeding was noted. 

The patient is diagnosed with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), meningitis, severe sepsis (with organ dysfunction), and hemolytic anemia. She is also suspected to have a Listeria brain abscess.

The patient's respiratory failure required intubation and tracheostomy for airway protection. Hemoptysis was initially noted but has since resolved. 

Regarding the patient's infection, she started on ampicillin and gentamicin for Listeria bacteremia and meningitis. The levels of gentamicin were adjusted based on therapeutic drug monitoring. The treatment duration will depend on the results of CSF culture, final read of MRI, input from ID and neurology teams, and is anticipated to be several weeks.

A lumbar puncture (LP) was completed on 9/28, which supports the clearing of infection, especially given the improvement in fever curve and hemodynamics. Cryptococcal antigen was negative, and modified cultures were sent for fungal and AFB testing. Monitoring of culture data is ongoing.

The patient's

The patient underwent tracheostomy and has been doing well on tracheostomy for several days now. Her mental status has shown marked improvement overnight. The patient is intubated for airway protection due to altered mental status and is currently on a tracheostomy. She is weaning off FiO2 and is currently at 35%. 

The patient continues to show improvement in her mental status. There is still an evaluation for neoplasm, but less concern for fungal infection given improved CSF, decreased fever curve, and unchanged head imaging. Awaiting repeat TEE to evaluate for endocarditis/abscess.

The patient has pancytopenia, which is an ongoing issue. Her WBC has improved, but Hct is down. She has been off all immunosuppressive agents for over two weeks. Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a past medical history of autoimmune disease. She presented with seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. The patient underwent a tracheostomy and has been doing well on a tracheostomy mask. Her mental status has shown marked improvement overnight.

The patient is currently intubated for respiratory failure and is being weaned off FiO2. She experienced an episode of hemoptysis, but bronchoscopy and CTA results were reassuring, suggesting that the bleeding was likely due to a small site of erosion.

The patient continues to show improvement in her mental status. There is still an evaluation for neoplasm, but less concern for fungal infection given the improved CSF, decreased fever curve, and unchanged head imaging. The patient is being treated with ampicillin and gentamicin, and ID, neurology, and follow-up cultures have been recommended.

The patient also has pancytopenia, which is an ongoing issue. Her WBC count has improved, but her Hct level is down. The patient has been off all immunosuppressive agents for over two weeks, and labs and smear have not been consistent with hemolysis. A TPMT test returned positive, indicating an increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment. There is ongoing concern for malignancy, and a hematologist-oncologist has

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), meningitis, severe sepsis, and hemolytic anemia. 

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 35.9°C
- Heart rate: 76-162 bpm
- Blood pressure: 109/54 mmHg
- Respiratory rate: 15-27 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation: 100% on T-piece with FiO2 35%

The patient has received multiple doses of antibiotics, including Ambisome, gentamicin, and ampicillin. They are also being given furosemide (Lasix) and other ICU medications.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. The creatinine levels are within normal range. Glucose levels are fluctuating, with some readings above normal.

Imaging shows a CXR, but there is no mention of any specific findings. The microbiology results from sputum on 10/2 indicate the presence of gram-negative rods.

The patient's physical examination reveals clear breath sounds, no murmurs, and intact eye movements. Neurologically, the patient is attentive, follows simple commands, and responds to verbal stimuli. However, there is limited movement on the right side, while the left side can move fingers and toes in small amounts.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 60-year-old female with a history of autoimmune disease who presented with seizure and was found to have Listeria bacteremia, meningitis, and a likely Listeria brain abscess. She underwent tracheostomy and has been doing well on tracheostomy. The patient is currently intubated for respiratory failure and is weaning off FiO2. She has had an episode of hemoptysis, but bronchoscopy and CTA were reassuring. There is GNR in the sputum, and a follow-up CXR is pending. The patient is continuing with ampicillin and gentamicin for Listeria bacteremia and meningitis. 

The patient also has pancytopenia, with improvement in WBC but a decrease in Hct. She has been off immunosuppressive agents for over two weeks, and labs and smear have not been consistent with hemolysis. TPMT returned positive, suggesting an increased risk of myelosuppression with Imuran treatment. There is an ongoing concern for malignancy, and a hematology reconsult has been done. F/u cytometry will be considered, along with a bone marrow biopsy. 

The patient's coagulation studies are stable, with an elevated INR that is likely secondary to nutritional deficiencies and liver disease. DIC appears to be less likely, but monitoring will continue. 

There are also issues related to autoimmune hepatitis, with LFTs trending
